review.title: Probabilistic Typology: Deep Generative Models of Vowel Inventories
review.abstract: Linguistic typology studies the range of structures present in human language. The main goal of the field is to discover which sets of possible phenomena are universal, and which are merely frequent. For example, all languages have vowels, while most---but not all---languages have an /u/ sound. In this paper we present the first probabilistic treatment of a basic question in phonological typology: What makes a natural vowel inventory? We introduce a series of deep stochastic point processes, and contrast them with previous computational, simulation-based approaches. We provide a comprehensive suite of experiments on over 200 distinct languages.

metadata.title: Probabilistic Typology: Deep Generative Models of Vowel Inventories

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Human languages exhibit a wide range of phenomena, within certain limits. However, some structures appear to occur more frequently or occur more frequently than others. Perhaps one of the simplest typological questions comes from phonology: Which vowels tend to occur and quantify within the phoneme inventories of different languages? Inspired by linguistic literature, we propose models of the probability distribution from which the certified vowel inventories were drawn. It is a typological universe in which each language contains both vowels and consonants (Velupillai, 2012). Which vowels a language contains is guided by softer constraints in which certain configurations are more common than others. In a typical phoneme inventory inventory, there tend to be far fewer vowels than consonants.

sections.heading: 2 Vowel Inventories and their Typology
sections.text: Vowel inventories are a simple entry point into the study of linguistic typology. Each spoken language chooses its own set of vowels, and the number of vowel phonemes ranges from 3 to 46, with an average of 8.7 (Gordon, 2016). Nevertheless, the empirical distribution over vowel inventories is remarkably high: the majority of languages have 5-7 vowels, and despite many possibilities, there are only a handful of different 4-vowel systems that are documented. Recurring linguistic theory (BeckerKristal, 2010) has suggested that vowel inventories are shaped by the principles discussed below.

sections.heading: 2.1 Acoustic Phonetics
sections.text: One way to describe the sound of a vowel is its acoustic energy at different frequencies. A spectrogram (Figure 3) is a visualization of the energy at different frequencies over time. Consider the "peak frequencies" F0 < F1 < F2 <..., which have a greater energy than their neighboring frequencies. F0 is referred to as the fundamental frequency or pitch. The other qualities of the vowel are largely determined by F1, F2,..., known as formants (Chargefoged and Johnson, 2014). In many languages, the first two formants F1 and F2 contain enough information to identify a vowel: Figure 3 shows how they differ between three English vowels. We consider each vowel listed in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) to be characterized as cross-linguistic by some (F1, F2) pairs.

sections.heading: 2.2 Dispersion
sections.text: The dispersion criterion (Liljencrants and Lindblom, 1972; Lindblom, 1986) states that the phonemes of a language must be "spread out" so that they can be easily distinguished from the listener. Language seeks phonemes that are sufficiently "far" from each other to avoid confusion. Distances between phonemes are defined in any latent "metric space." We use this term as a reflection of their similarity, rather than their similarity.

sections.heading: 2.3 Focalization
sections.text: A commonly accepted explanation is the Quantum Theory of Speech (Stevens, 1972, 1989). Quantum Theory states that certain sounds are easier to articulate and perceive than others. These vowels can be characterized as those where F1 and F2 frequencies are close to each other. On the production side, these vowels are easier to pronounce because they allow greater imprecision in articulation. On the perception side, they are more prominent because the two spectral peaks aggregate and act as one, larger peaks to some extent. Generally, languages will prefer these vowels.

sections.heading: 3 Point Process Models
sections.text: In this essay, we take V as a set of all IPA symbols corresponding to the vowels. Thus, a dot process is a vowel inventory V, and the dot process itself is a distribution over such inventories. We consider three basic dot process models for vowel systems: the Bernoulli dot process, the Markov dot process, and the determinant dot process. In this section, we review the relevant theory of dot processes, highlighting aspects related to § 2.

sections.heading: 6 Evaluation Metrics
sections.text: Essentially, we are interested in whether our model has abstracted the basic principles of what constitutes a good vowel system. Our choice of a probabilistic model represents a natural test: How surprised is our model of held-up languages? In other words, how likely is it that our model goes unheeded, but attested vowel systems are? This is a natural evaluation paradigm in the NLP, but - to the best of our knowledge - it has not been applied to a quantitative study of linguistic typology. As a second evaluation, we are introducing a vowel system cloze task, which could also be used to evaluate non-probabilistic models. sections.heading: 7 Experiments
sections.text: We evaluate our models on the basis of a 10-fold cross-validation in the 223 languages. We specify the mean performance in the 10 folds. Performance in each fold ("test") was determined by training many models in 8 of the other 9 folds ("pull"), selecting the model that achieved the best task-specific performance in the remaining fold ("development"), and evaluating these on the test fold. Minimization of the parameters is done using the L-BFGS algorithm (Liu and Nocedal, 1989). As a pre-processing step, the first two formant values F1 and F2 are centered by a factor of zero and scaled down by a factor of 1000, since the formant values themselves can be quite large. sections.heading: 8 Discussion: Probabilistic Typology
sections.text: We see this as a natural approach to typology because it directly describes which types of linguistic systems occur more or less frequently. In fact, the traditional implicit universal concepts ("all languages with vi have vj") have been softened in our approach to conditional probabilities, such as "p (vj) evolutionary types of linguistic systems." This is not merely an empirical relationship, but a probability derived from the fully estimated distribution. It is meant to make predictions about invisible languages that exploit the properties of these distribution10. Jakobson (1941) found that children's acquired phonemes reflect in an order the principles of similar dispersion ("maximum contrast") and focalization.At each rate, we estimate the distribution of certain systems that go beyond the typology.

sections.heading: 9 Conclusions
sections.text: We have presented a series of point process models for modeling the inventory typology of the vowel system, with the aim of providing a mathematical basis for research in phonological typology. In addition, all models were given in-depth parameterization to learn representations that resemble the perceptual space in cognitive science. Furthermore, we have established our preference for probabilistic modelling in linguistic typology over previously proposed computerized approaches, arguing that it is a more natural research paradigm. In addition, we have introduced several new evaluation metrics for research in vowel system typology that we hope will spark further interest in this area. Their performance has been empirically confirmed in the Becker-Kristal corpus, which includes data from over 200 languages.
